title: Effect of HCl Conc on Reaction Rate

content.description: A <math alttext="0.50 gram" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="M g, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was placed in a solution of <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where it reacted completely.
content.question: In a third experiment, <math alttext="0.10 gram " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> samples of <math alttext="M g, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Mg</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are placed in excess <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HC</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> of various concentrations: <math alttext="0.050 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.050</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="0.10 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="0.25 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.25</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The reactions are run in successive order from <math alttext="0.050 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.050</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the time required for each reaction to go to completion is recorded. As the concentration of <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> increases from <math alttext="0.050 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.050</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0.50 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, which of the following is the expected result?

choices.label: The reaction time increases, and the rate of the reaction decreases.
The reaction time decreases, and the rate of the reaction increases.
Both the reaction time and the rate of the reaction increase.
Both the reaction time and the rate of the reaction decrease.

content.answer: The reaction time decreases, and the rate of the reaction increases.

skill.text: 2.B: Formulate a hypothesis or predict the results of an experiment.
